question: Postnatally when is the growth velocity maximum?
exp: Postnatally there are 2 periods of accelerated growth: first year of life and growth spu during pubey.
opa: In the first year of life
opb: In the second year of life
opc: In the seventh year of life

question: The weight of the child at 3 years is usually ___ times the bih weight?
exp: The increase in the weight of the child with age- Age Weight (kg) Bih w 5 months 2w 1 year 3w 2 years 4w 3 years 5w

question: Which of the following curve best demonstrates somatic growth- Here X-axis is age in years.
exp: Option (b) - Demonstrates somatic growth curve which follows a sigmoid shape Option (a) - Demonstrates Brain growth. The brain size/ head size in neonate is about 65-70% of the expected head size in adults. It reaches 90% of the adult head size by the age of 2 years. Option (c) - Demonstrates lymphoid growth. Lymphoid growth is most active between 4-8 years of age after which it slows down. Option (d) - Demonstrates gonadal growth which peaks during pubescence.

question: Which X ray is used to determine bone age in a 3 year old child?
exp: To determine the skeletal age in infants between 3 and 9 months age, X ray of shoulder is most useful. X ray of hand and wrist is most useful for children between 1 and 13 year age.

question: Delayed dentition is usually considered when there are no teeth by the age of?
exp: Delayed dentition is usually considered when there are no teeth has erupted by the age of 13 months Normally temporary teeth eruption is completed by 2 to 2. 5yr of age

question: Embryonic period is upto:
exp: Embryonic Period Day of feilization ( 14th day post-ovulation) to 8 weeks* intrauterine life Fetal period 9 weeks to Bih Perinatal Period 28 weeks to 7 days of postnatal life

question: Bih length doubles by what age?
exp: Bih length doubles by 4- 4 1/2 yrs of age Age Bih 1 year 2 year 4 year 12 year Height 50 cm 75 cm 90 cm 100 cm 150 cm Length of child increases by 50% in 1st year.

question: A 1 yr 5 month old boy was brought to the Pediatrics OPD by his mother. She complained that her son did not have any teeth till then. All of the following could be the underlying causes EXCEPT?
exp: Delayed dentition: - When no tooth has erupted by the age of 13 months. Answer is Pierre Robin sequence- cause of natal teeth

question: How many permanent teeth will be present in a 8 year old child?
exp: Permanent teeth erupt in the following order: First molar 6-7 years Central and lateral incisors 6-8 years Canine and premolars 9-12 years Second molar 12-13 years Third molar 18 years or later So at the age of 8 years first molar, central and lateral incisors would have erupted in each quadrant Hence, totally 12 permanent teeth will be present at the age of 8 years

question: Best indicator of growth monitoring in children
exp: Rate of increase in height or weight as age advances- Best indicator of growth monitoring in children Uses of growth cha:- 1) For growth monitoring 2) Diagnostic tool for identifying "high risk" children 3) Planning and policy making 4) Education tool 5) Tool for action Mid arm circumference, Body weight and chest circumference are one time point estimates therefore they are not adequate to provide information about long term nutritional status of the child.
opc: Rate of increase in height & weight

question: The teeth abnormality seen below is seen in which of the following diseases?
exp: The teeth abnormality shown - 'Hutchinson's teeth', which are notched incisors, seen in Congenital Syphilis. Hutchinsons triad- Huchtinsons teeth, Interstitial keratitis, SNHL Cleidocranial Dysostosis- Malocclusion of jaw, delayed appearance of 2ndry teeth and prolonged persistence of primary teeth (peg like teeth) Congenital hypothyroidism -Delayed eruption of teeth Congenital Rubella - CRS ( cataract, Heart disease-PDA, SHNL), have exaggerated dental problems

question: Delayed dentition is seen in:
exp: Causes of delayed dentition: Familial Rickets* Idiopathic; Incontinentiapigmenti* Endocrine causes*: Hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypopituitarism Down syndrome* Cleidocranial dysplasia Progeria Advanced dentition- Seen in: o Precocious pubey* o Hypehyroidism*

question: What is the name of this device, used to measure subscapular skin fold thickness?
exp: Harpenden callipers- used to measure the skin fold thickness. Measured over the following areas:- Subscapular Biceps Triceps areas. Other options:- Orchidometer- used to measure volume of testicles. Shakir's tape- used to measure MUAC Vernier callipers- used to measure diameter of object

question: 'Nocturnal enuresis' refers to involuntary urination at night beyond the age of?
exp: 'Nocturnal enuresis' refers to involuntary urination at night beyond the age of 5 years Normal milestones: 18 months: Dry during daytime 3 years: Dry at night

question: All are unique features of WHO growth chas 2006 EXCEPT:
exp: WHO growth chas- based upon MGRS (Multicentre Growth Reference Study) conducted in 6 countries across the world including India. Babies who were breastfed for at least first few months of life were included. Includes new indicators such as skinfold thickness Reiterates children grow similarly across the World
opa: It establishes breastfed infant as normative growth model
opb: Sample collected from ten countries including India
opc: Includes new indicators such as skinfold thickness
opd: Reiterates children grow similarly across the World

question: What is the following device used to measure?
exp: Orchidometer-used to measure testicular size - Stretch the scrotal skin and measure testicular size with orchidometer. - Testicular enlargement first sign of pubey in boys For the assessment of pubey -Tanner's staging or SMR (Sexual Maturity rating) Pubey in females: 1st sign - Thelarche (development of breast buds)

question: Which of the following is true about the growth cha shown below?
exp: Discussing about the options one by one, a. False; It is the weight for age growth cha, not a growth velocity cha b. False; Wasting is decrease in weight for height, but this is a weight for age cha e. True; It is used for serial assessment of growth status of a girl c. False; It can be used to detect 'failure to thrive' i. e. not gaining weight properly
opa: It is a growth velocity curve
opb: It can be used to know whether a child has wasting or not
opc: It is used for serial assessment of growth status of a girl

question: Height of children in 2 - 10 years of age is increased by:
exp: Height Velocity in Children: Age Normal range 2 - 5 years 6 cm/ year* 5 - 10 years 5-6 cm/year

question: All are true about anthropometric measurements except:-
exp: Standing height is about 0. 7 cm less than recumbent length. If a child < 2 years old, measure recumbent length- Infantometer If >= 2-year age and able to stand, measure standing height- Stadiometer
opb: Skinfold thickness is measured in sub scapular region
opc: Weight is measured to the nearest 100 gram
opd: Standing height is about 2. 5 cm more than recumbent length

question: Salter's Scale is a useful method employed in the field to measure:
exp: Bathroom weighing scale is unreliable instrument for measuring weight of children For field conditions, Salter's Spring Scale is quite satisfactory as it is easy to carry.

question: Rao and Singh's index is?
exp: RAO & SINGH'S INDEX: - It is calculated as Weight (in kg) x 100/height2 (in cm) - Normal value: 0. 14 - In children with malnutrition: 0. 12 - 0. 14
